TopicTitle: How to determine the distance from Kerbin to another Planet?

Articles.Content:
I am not the best at mathematics and would like to learn a little more about Rocketry. To determine the distance from Kerbin to another Planet at it's semi-major axis I am guessing would be the farthest but if an actual trip in the real world we would most likely travel the shortest distance from A to B. My question as an example, what would be the trip distance from Kerbin to Eeloo if I were to make the trip in the real world?

Edited August 29, 2015 by castille7
Answered

Do you mean the distance that the pod actually travels? Because in KSP and IRL, this distance would always be much, much further than the actual distance between point A and B, in fact distance AB will probably change significantly during the journey.

I'm not sure if I am teaching you to suck eggs or not, I'll just assume you're a total no0b, just ignore it if its all obvious, Im certainly not the most expert here.

The most efficient route from A to B (if we assume A and B are celestial bodies) is a Hohmann transfer. This basically entails either lowering your periapsis to match the targets orbital height (or raising your apoapsis to match, depending on where you are going.) You time the tranfer so that when you arrive at apo/periapsis, that is when the target passes that point, and you circularise your orbit.

So total distance covered by your vehicle is somewhere between 1 half of the orbital circumference of object A and 1 half of the orbital circumference of object B. I think the maths to figure out the exact distance would be fairly involved.

Note that this is not the only way to travel, but this way requires the least dV. There is a transfer planner mod that can help you a great deal in timing your launches and planning for dV, I think it might even calculate the exact distance travelled for you as well, Im not sure.

(You can actually get from A to B with less dV, but this requires the use of gravitational assists around other bodies.)

Some good info here:

http://www.phy6.org/stargaze/Smars1.htm

The funny thing about KSP (and orbital mechanics) is that while you can calculate the distance in kilometers, it's hardly useful. The useful measurement is m/s of delta-V. Like, my asteroid-based refuelling station is 300m/s away from LKO.

The direct distance is useful only with RemoteTech with signals travelling at speed of light, to determine delay between the signal and reaction of given probe. For all practical purposes the distance is "how much delta-V you have to expend to get there".

Forgive me if I'm wrong, but I think you might have a more basic misconception about how interplanetary craft travel.

In RL (and in KSP) crafts are launched when both planets are still far apart. It's important to realise that although the ship might leave its parent planet in a fairly straight line, it still travels in circles/ellipses around the sun, and never ever travels in a straight line from one planet to the next. Interplanetary missions always rely on changing the shape of the circle/ellipse to make things line up or pass close to each other, not by stopping and setting off in a different direction - that would be technically possible, but it would be very, very inefficient.

So, the shortest distance between two planets (often called the closest approach) is interesting and useful to astronomers or stargazers (because it gives a particularly good view of other planets), but not so useful to rocketry.
